measurement is applicable to any amylase, in general it refers to the combined
Î±-amylase and Î²-amylase used in brewing. The term is also generalized to
diastatic malt extracts and separately prepared brewing enzymes. The

JECFA, the Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives, defines the degree
Lintner as follows: :A malt has a diastatic power of 100 Â°L if 0.1[[Cubic
metre|cc]] of a clear 5% infusion of the malt, acting on 100cc of a 2%
[[starch]] solution at 20Â°C for one [[hour]], produces sufficient reducing
sugars to reduce completely 5cc of [[Fehling's solution]].

Note that the amylases used in brewing reach their peak efficiencies
around 66 Â°C.

Evaluation of a malt or extract is usually done by the manufacturer rather than
by the end user; as a rule of thumb, the total grain bill of a mash should have
a diastatic power of at least 40 Â°L in order to guarantee efficient conversion
of all the starches in the mash to sugars.
